video.title: Docker Tutorial for Beginners - A Full DevOps Course on How to Run Applications in Containers
video.description:
Get started using Docker with this end-to-end beginners course with hands-on labs.

Docker is an open platform for developers and sysadmins to build, ship, and run distributed applications, whether on laptops, data center VMs, or the cloud.

In this course you will learn Docker through a series of lectures that use animation, illustration and some fun analogies that simply complex concepts, we have demos that will show how to install and get started with Docker and most importantly we have hands-on labs that you can access right in your browser. 

💻 Practice Labs: https://bit.ly/3IxaqRN

🔗 KodeKloud Website: https://www.kodekloud.com

🎥 Tutorial from KodeKloud. Check out their Youtube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/mmumshad

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:02:35) Docker Overview
⌨️ (0:05:10) Getting Started
⌨️ (0:16:58) Install Docker
⌨️ (0:21:00) Commands
⌨️ (0:29:00) Labs
⌨️ (0:33:12) Run
⌨️ (0:42:19) Environment Variables
⌨️ (0:44:07) Images
⌨️ (0:51:38) CMD vs ENTRYPOINT
⌨️ (0:58:37) Networking
⌨️ (1:03:55) Storage
⌨️ (1:16:27) Compose
⌨️ (1:34:49) Registry
⌨️ (1:39:38) Engine
⌨️ (1:46:20) Docker on Windows
⌨️ (1:53:22) Docker on Mac
⌨️ (1:55:20) Container Orchestration
⌨️ (1:59:25) Docker Swarm

⌨️ (2:03:21) Kubernetes
⌨️ (2:09:30) Conclusion

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Shrinidhi G
topLevelComment.text:
I'm new to docker and I've got a doubt for which I'm not able to find the answer anywhere. Can someone please help me clear this doubt. 
Assuming we are running dockers on a Linux machine. I've learnt that docker container uses the underlying kernal of the OS which is installed. It interacts with the kernal directly. 
But still the very first line of the container image has a FROM UBUNTU, FROM REDHAT, etc declaration. When the container is run it'll download the specified OS image and first run that container, then this container/application we are intending to run will start. 
1> What is the purpose of pullling the OS image, when it can use the OS on which dockers is installed ? 
2> in the first place why do we even need an OS layer when dockers communicates directly with kernal and it hasgot nothing to do with the any OS 
3> Also if it has to download and run OS, what is the difference between VM and Containers ? even VM has its own OS... 
4> how does container become lightweight if it carries an OS of it own on every instance/run ?

topLevelComment.author: Likhith K P
topLevelComment.text:
Awesome video. Firstly I would like to appreciate the effort taken by the author.
I have a question regarding docker links - 
As explained in the Networking section (1:02:03), containers can reach each other using their names if they are hosted on the same node. When we are creating a version 1 docker-compose file (1:23:00), why do we need to use links to make the container aware of each other?
Am I missing anything?

replies.author: Faither
replies.text: Docker containers can indeed reach each other via IP addresses directly in the same network (e.g. default bridge). However, an IP address of a container may change with each start. Since a Docker link adds an entry to "/etc/hosts" file of a container based on a container name, it relatively guarantees that the IP address of a particular container matches with the required hostname when resolved.

topLevelComment.author: Adrian Zyskowski
topLevelComment.text:
To be precise: Docker doesn't download the whole operating system. These are not really operating systems, they are Linux distributions that have their filesystems packaged into a container filesystem.  You are not managing devices or even running the kernel of that operating system, only using their tools (e.g. apt-get, yum, or apk) to manage the contents of the container.

So Docker on Linux -> uses host linux kernel
Docker on windows -> uses Windows Subsystem for Linux kernel
Docker on mac -> uses Linux host VM kernel

topLevelComment.text:
There is an error in the "Docker run --links" slide. Running postgres and result-app containers is all mixed up. At 1:21:26 

Current:
docker run -d --name=db postgres:9.4 --link db:db result-app
docker run -d --name=result -p 5001:80

This is wrong as the "result" container doesn't even have an image specified, and the "db" container has two image names given. Also, the "--link db:db" should be done for "result" container

What it should be:
docker run -d --name=db postgres:9.4 
docker run -d --name=result -p 5001:80 --link db:db result-app

Please let me know if I am wrong!

Am I wrong in interpreting that it's the application developers/providers who host them in containers, and there's no change on the end user side in how they consume the service?  Am I way behind the curve here?

topLevelComment.author: Upcycle Electronics
topLevelComment.text:
@freecodecamp
I am looking for more content like this. I scrolled through your entire library looking for an upload about AppArmor, FireJail, and IPTables.

  Back story in a nutshell: After installing Arch for the first time, I learned linux security the hard way. Within 48 hours, I lost control of PAM to port 22. It's no big deal. I overwrote the drive.
   After that, I came across several lectures by Aaron Jones posted on a small YT channel with the name Brian Cluff, (I have no affiliation with either party). He does some interesting presentations on Linux security. Like the Arch Linux Wiki, Aaron's presentations are more abstract guides as opposed to stepped tutorials.
   Aaron is a big proponent of Docker, thus the reason I searched and watched this upload. He does a good job of explaining security. I've fumbled my way through installing AppArmor, FireJail, raw IPTables and then UFW. Aaron also recommended the IceCat web browser, and notes his distrust of JavaScript. 
  His day job is for the Arizona Police Department, has a masters in (?something related to?) Computer Science, and (IIRC) received his credentials while serving in the US military. He's someone to be aware of if you're looking for potential content to showcase. His stuff on YT is done on his own time for a local linux users group.
  Anyways, in my quest to learn embedded hardware, I'm to the point where I want to learn more about networking and security. I'm often searching obscure references, looking in foreign language forums, and downloading from dubious sources trying to learn about some chip I've come across or want to use. Assuming one day I will be working for someone that is on the other side of proprietary IP, I would like to have a better understanding of how to sandbox and segment applications access, especially with the risk of JavaScript and bots on the web. I have not been successful finding effective tutorial content on AppArmor, FireJail, and a comprehensive Firewall addressing all ports while still allowing a fully dev-capable machine. I want to be able to address things like proprietary code and it's network access. I want to know how to monitor and filter all access within and outside of my machine. 
  Also I'm interested in a guide on effective management of logging in conjunction with SSD's. We all (should) have SSD's  now, and unmanaged logging is one of the quickest paths to buying a new one. A comprehensive guide to securing a development workstation that fails to address logging and SSD's is incomplete IMO.
  This is just a piece of the dev's pie I think you're missing in the current camp library. I hope you find something good to fill the void.
 Thanks for all you do here.
-Jake

topLevelComment.author: Prometheus720
topLevelComment.text:
This is one of the greatest tutorials for anything I have ever tried to learn in my life.

One of the best parts of this is that you take the time to explain the history and development of Docker so that we understand why certain things work the way that they do. A great example is when you explain why docker-compose.yml files NEED to have the version number at the top, or why they DON'T need links in the same way.

You have incredible animations and good presentation skills, and everything is crystal-clear. I am so, so impressed and grateful. I am not a programmer or developer. I might be described as a power-user, but I very rarely write any code at all. I have found this tutorial to be very easy to follow even for someone with super limited knowledge of the programming world. For example, I know next to nothing about most of the systems we are running in the voting app stack. I have never used any of them or written anything in any of them. Even so, you made it easy for me to follow along and focus on DOCKER, not those other things.

This is the gold standard and I hope you and anyone else who worked on it are proud of this series. You certainly should be.

topLevelComment.author: Osama_ Momani
topLevelComment.text:
1:26:00 
why to use links if there is a local DNS in the network that resolves each container name with it is internal ip?

replies.author: Osama_ Momani
replies.text:
found it :)   -- 
Links have been replaced by networks. (Docker describes them as a legacy feature that you should avoid using). You can safely remove the link and the two containers will be able to refer to each other by their service name (or container_name).

replies.author: Martin Bedon
replies.text: I had the same problem, what I did was: 1) go to the folder    2)  docker build -t imageNAME .     NOTE: after imageNAME is space and a dot

replies.author: Shubham Jaiswal
replies.text: By default the build command needs the location of directory where a file named "Dockerfile" is present. So if you are in the directory with the Dockerfile, just use "docker build ." ( . means current directory). Use the -f or --file FILENAME option for a custom file.

This is an amazing course. With that, I have a bunch of questions. 
1. Say if I create a new container from an mongo image, and then I stop that container,  and then want to rerun that container, should I use docker run with that base image or use docker start/stop. 


for example: I want to launch a MongoDB container. 


`docker run --name mongo-container mongo`


I stop it with 


`docker container stop mongo-container`


and then rerun it 


`docker container start mongo-container`


how come when I first ran docker run mongo, I could see the mongo daemen in my terminal but then when I stop and then start the container it won't show up in my terminal? Does this have to do with docker run being in attached mode by default? or if I run the container using docker start its in detached mode? 


2. How do I know what map network to map to that specific container? 


like for mongo I did this 


`docker run -p 27017-27019:27017-27019 --name mongo-container -v mongoVol:/app mongo:latest`


3. the same goes for volume mapping, how do I know the path I'm mapping to? In section VOLUMES around 1h14s in the video: 


The command for mounting:   docker run  -v data_volume:/var/lib/mysql mysql  This didn't work for me. I needed to specify password for mysql as below:


docker run -e MYSQL_ALLOW_EMPTY_PASSWORD =yes -v data_volume:/var/lib/mysql mysql


I don't know if anybody got that problem but I wanted to share in case somebody having the issue.


PS: Beautiful video. Thanks a lot!
